author: Tim_Johnson
title: Letters and numbers, letters and numbers!
review:
Hurrah for the return of letter and number tiles. I could end this review there really.

You also get a PRINTED 2x2 tile of the LEGO logo, wonderful!... and two natty 1x2 ".com" tiles and basic punctuation for writing your email address, cute. Two minifigs in blue overalls are included along with a few nice long plates, a bracket and basic pieces. The minifig stands are 3x3 round corner plates - weird they didn't use the CMF stands, but I'm glad they didn't!

There is one paper business card included also. It is LEGO branded. I wonder if it will get me into Billund. Otherwise, it's probably useless unless you regularly forget your own personal details. 

It's the most basic of 'builds' but you can't underestimate the fun of typesetting your own name and email in LEGO. There are between 1 and 3 of each tile, so definitely buy multiples. 

There are no accented letters this time around. I think the font is the same as previous sets, looks like the LEGO corporate font.

I imagine the vast majority of AFOLs will get this purely as a parts pack, unless you genuinely like multi primary coloured things on your desk.

author: FizzleMeSexy
title: Letters
review:
Purchased this set strictly for the letter and number tiles. I typically purchase sets for minifigures however I wish this set excluded them for more lettering.

There are three of all the numbers, and letters: A, E, J, K, P.
One U, Y, Z, "-", Lego logo
Two of the remaining alphabet, ".", "_", "@", ".com"

Simple build: If the parts were larger it would have younger then the 6+ rating.

I expected the tiles to be black with white print. The tiles are Black with SILVER print. It was a pleasant surprise unless you were looking for white print for your MOC.

In short...
Overall: 4/5 - When you need lettering, you need lettering.
Building experience: 1/5 - Nothing too boot about
Parts: 4/5 Silver lettering & Lego logo are great additions to a collection
Playability: 1/5 - As a set you'll only build this once [if that]
Value for money: 3/5 - The piece to price ratio isn't terrible based off the package but I would prefer it for less and without the two minifigures.

author: FlagsNZ
title: Lego's Minifigure Scrabble set
review:
I bought this set along with the pencil holder to boost my Lego Maersk Line Triple E ship order above $300 and therefore get free shipping.

Despite this, I am glad of the purchase and both these sets look good accessorising my office desk.

Parts

The striking parts in this set are the 1x1 black tiles with silver lettering. Other reviews have inventoried the letters so I won't do that here.

I would recommend purchasing two of these sets to increase the choice of letters you have available.

Minifigures

I have constructed this model to have the two minifgures play Scrabble. This set could further be customised and used as a giant Scrabble set in a City park.

The build

There is little skill required to build this model. The real skill come when designing your Lego business card. I have made a diagonal crossword puzzle to fit everything I wanted to say on the card.

As I said, if you get two sets, you will have better options.

The completed model

It does look good. I have really raised awareness of Lego at my work. ; )

Overall opinion

As a business card holder, it actually works really well. It has a real use on your desk and therefore it is functional and not only a toy.

author: Gerbil
title: Awesome letters, odd distribution. Need to buy multiples.
review:
I've wanted this set for a long time as I'm such as stickler for LEGO products that I want even my display text to be done in it when we do exhibitions.
However, it went out of production a long time ago, and the nearest replacement was the book with letters in different colours. This too is now out of production.

So imagine my surprise when our national online LEGO store in Colombia had them for sale!

I don't know how or why, but at roughly $20 USD I had to partake. I ended up buying 10!

The letters themselves are amazing - well printed and in a metallic ink. In the photos they often look white, but they reflect the light and not only are always easy to read, but look lovely. The LEGO tile is also very welcome.

The other pieces are nothing special, normal bricks and plates in a variety of primary colours, and the figures, while nice are nothing special. One is male, the other female, although they only differ by the heads.

So what's bad about it? The strange letter distribution. Worst of all is that every letter gets at least 2 copies except for the U, which only comes with 1. This is fairly ridiculous, particularly when you think even the Qs and Xs of the world get more. Vowels really should have been 2 minimum, and it would have cost LEGO virtually nothing to add more in.

Basically, if you really fancy writing things in LEGO, this is your best (only real) option, but you are almost certainly going to need many copies, and if you need to write something with a lot of U's, then... well, it is going to be tough!

It loses an overall star because of this.

I love this set, and it is really adds the final touch to our scenes, as these photos will hopefully show. But you really, really need to buy multiples and at this point, that's going to be almost impossible.

Here's hoping LEGO comes out with something similar in the future!
